answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Hi Kathleen, 
Peak Democracy has been working with variety of large municipalities and small towns across the US to increase the quantity and quality of on-line communication between residents and their local governments.  
Peak Democracy provides an online public comment platform (called Open City Hall) that augments and diversifies feedback from residents to local governments.  
Our service is easy to set-up, cost-effective to operate, and it integrates with local government social media (i.e. Facebook and Twitter).  
To learn more about this opportunity, you can contact me at 866-535-8894 x701 or mike@PeakDemocracy.com. 
Thanks, 
Mike 
Peak Democracy Inc 
http://www.PeakDemocracy.com

answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
I think  a major question is "what IS significant use?"
We know people come to look for jobs, the hit counts verify that. That is where things like Google Analytics can help you a  lot. But that data needs to be compared against a base - that base is the existing level of non-web contacts.
If you know how many citizen contact phone calls come in, and how many walkups come in per day, then you can rationally look at your daily web traffic and you may find it already is significant.
I think we as professionals need to understand that there is a qualitative difference in "customer" related traffic from more participatory "Public Engagement". I think that the Public Engagement piece is a far more difficult issue, than redirecting customer traffic.

text: What techniques has your community used to drive your resident inquiries to the website? We are working hard to get people to use it as a resource, make it their first stop in the information gathering journey and still find that we don't have significant use.
title: Driving Residents and others to the Website
